conclusion: Analyze conditions for gas leakage using given parameters and ideal gas equation.

Image shows a hollow insulated cylinder with two chambers divided by a diaphragm of mass m, filled with helium at pressure p and temperature T. Cylinder height is 2H and volume is 2V. Piston moves upwards slowly.
Initially, both chambers have the same volume V and pressure p.
Diaphragm is at rest on the ledge, gas is in equilibrium.
When piston moves upwards, volume of lower chamber decreases to V_0.
Diaphragm starts to move when pressure difference between chambers becomes significant.
Pressure difference is given by Δp = mg/A, where A is cross-sectional area.
Condition for leakage is when pressure difference equals pressure in lower chamber, Δp = p.
Using Δp = mg/A = p, find x = mgH/pV.
Solve for V_0 when leakage begins: V_0 = V(1 - mgH/pV).
Substitute x = mgH/pV to get V_0 = V(1 - mgH/pV).
Simplify to V_0 = V(1 - mgH/pV) = V(1 - x).
Volume of lower chamber when leakage begins is V_0 = V(1 - x).
